urn:contentItem:5S40-H2G1-F19Y-C1CF-00000-00Balancing innovation, regulation as EU's digital market falls behind China, US2018-04-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:09ZLexisNexisExclusiveBalancing innovation, regulation as EU's digital market falls behind China, USVinjeru Mkandawire

Europe's digital single market is being hailed as proof that government regulation can have a positive impact on private market innovation. But questions remain about the region's competitiveness on the global stage.

Europe's Digital Single Market has ushered in a wave of technology-focused policies and paved the way for regulatory reforms, but questions remain about the region's competitiveness on the global stage.

After adopting the single market strategy in 2015, the EU abolished mobile roaming charges across its member states last year and this month introduced new rules allowing cross-border access to online subscription services such as Netflix Inc. and Amazon.com Inc. The European Commission also recently unveiled plans for a 3% tax on the revenues of tech companies, while next month the new General Data Protection Regulation comes into force, designed to strengthen rules around how EU citizens' data is stored, shared and managed.

But the EU, once a leader in mobile technology, is now a laggard, and while officials are urging governments to do more to harmonize rules and promote investment, some industry figures believe overregulation might condemn the region to falling further behind.

"Without removing barriers that prevent digital growth, without the right legal environment, without adequate investment, Europe will not have much of a digital future," Andrus Ansip, vice president of the European Commission, told delegates at the organization's Digital Day 2018 in Brussels on April 10.

The EU heavyweight added that member states were already in the process of agreeing on a new telecom policy aimed at making 5G fifth generation mobile networks a reality.

At the same time, Ansip urged individual European governments to invest more in areas such as artificial intelligence, digital healthcare and blockchain technology in order to catch up with global peers such as China and the U.S.

"There is quite some ground to catch up. Other continents are moving ahead quickly," Ansip said.

He did warn, however, that "our public purse only goes so far," representing about 1% of the wealth that EU economies generate every year.

When it comes to artificial intelligence, identified by Ansip as a key priority for the European community, China and the U.S. lead by a comfortable margin. Research from data company CB Insights shows that China accounted for 48% of global AI startup funding in 2017, followed by the U.S. with 38%.

Panelists noted that Europe has also fallen behind in other areas, including fiber, 5G, robotics, blockchain and cloud computing.

Europe once boasted the leading mobile manufacturers, operators, standards, and technologies, according to John Strand, CEO of telecoms consultancy Strand Consult.

Speaking independently from the event, he argued that "while the EU had preeminence in mobile, it failed to create the companies that powered the internet and is already behind the curve on 5G."

He added that more "draconian" regulation could harm the region, rather than empower it.

Comparing the global prospects for 5G alone, research from CCS Insight shows Europe trailing its international peers. The firm estimates that China will pass 100 million connections in 2021 before amassing 1 billion connections in 2025, while Western Europe is only likely to hit the 100 million mark by early 2023.

"We are not leading in these kind of fields we have to change this," urged Matthias Machnig, state secretary at the Federal Ministry of Economic Affairs and Energy in Germany. It is necessary to ensure that government intervention does not curb innovation, he explained at the event in Brussels.

"We need a legal framework, policies, regulation, standards," Machnig said. "[But] are we making progress or are we blocking certain developments?"

Despite concerns about overregulation, the panelists agreed that big tech's impact on social issues, including jobs, demand for education and healthcare, would continue to make government intervention necessary.

Citing social inclusion and equipping workers with tech skills as crucial elements of any government policy, Portugal's minister of science, technology and higher education, Manuel Heitor, cautioned against excluding Europe's "digital divide" from political debate.

The European Commission's own findings on the digital divide published in 2015 found that increasing broadband penetration is linked to innovation, with a 10% increase in broadband boosting GDP by as much as 1.5%.

Also wading into the debate, Roberto Viola, director general of the European Commission's department responsible for developing a digital single market, raised the alarm over what developments in big data would mean for the future storage of personal data, include genome records.

He therefore argued that public governance would continue to "make sense" for policing the handling of sensitive data.

"If you're going to build new services based on [this new technology], you need solid and secure infrastructure that can keep private data [safe]," he concluded, adding "that's why public intervention is there."

urn:contentItem:5TWX-5DT1-JCMP-54HN-00000-00Banca española reclama desventaja en protección de datos2018-12-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:09ZLexisNexisBanca española reclama desventaja en protección de datosExpansión





El sector bancario español ha visto cómo la directiva europea de servicios de pago (PSD2), que entró en vigor el pasado mes de enero, se ha ido desarrollando a lo largo de este año y que culminará en el 2019, obligará a todos los bancos a entregar datos de clientes a terceros y competidores de otros sectores que hayan obtenido un consentimiento expreso para ello.





Esta medida, planteada por las autoridades comunitarias como un impulso a la competencia en el sector financiero, tiene en pie de guerra a los bancos españoles que, tanto a través del presidente de la Asociación Española de Banca (AEB), José María Roldán, como a través de la presidenta de Santander, Ana Botín, llevan meses alertando sobre la existencia de una «asimetría regulatoria» que sitúa en una posición competitiva de desventaja a las entidades frente a compañías tecnológicas o de sectores como las telecomunicaciones.



Santander, BBVA y CaixaBank consideran que las autoridades europeas tienen que revisar su marco regulatorio sobre protección de datos para equilibrar la actual situación (que obliga a las entidades a proporcionar datos a terceros), de forma que grandes tecnológicas como Google, Amazon o Facebook, así como los operadores de telecomunicaciones, abran también sus datos a terceros que hayan obtenido un consentimiento por parte de los usuarios.



Así lo manifestaron durante la celebración de las segundas jornadas Banking Lab, organizadas por la AEB en la escuela de finanzas Cunef, en Madrid. En opinión de Álvaro Martín, economista especializado en regulación financiera de BBVA, “una mayor competencia es buena, pero tiene que haber un punto en el que se tiene que reequilibrar para evitar ventajas injustas”, indicó, durante su participación en el debate.



Un análisis similar expuso Gloria Hervás, manager de Public Policy en Santander, para quien el péndulo regulatorio se fue demasiado lejos en cuanto a la apertura a nuevos competidores, obligando sólo a los bancos a abrir sus datos a terceros. “Hay que explorar la conveniencia de que los datos de otras compañías puedan ser transmitidos a terceros, siempre con consentimiento”, propuso.



Hervás apostó por “desconsolidar” parte de las actividades más innovadoras dentro del sector bancario y fintech, de forma que se sitúen al margen de los elevados costos que conllevan la regulación bancaria. “A lo mejor hay que pensar en negocios que queden fuera de esta supervisión bancaria tan estricta”, opinó.



“Los reguladores tienen el reto de mantener un campo de juego equilibrado preservando la seguridad y la entrada de nuevos competidores”, señaló por su parte Xavier Vives, profesor de Economía y Finanzas de la escuela de negocios IESE y consejero independiente de CaixaBank.

Competencia para las actividades más rentables 

Precisamente para analizar el desafío que supone para la banca la competencia de gigantes como Google, Amazon o Facebook, el encuentro organizado por la AEB en Cunef presentó el estudio Big tech banking, firmado por Miguel de la Mano y Jorge Padilla, de la consultora especializada en temas de competencia Compass Lexecon.



Los autores del estudio consideran que, “inicialmente”, la entrada de las grandes tecnológicas en el sector bancario puede suponer un impacto positivo en cuanto a una mayor competencia. Sin embargo, advierten que a largo plazo la banca se expone a un desafío existencial, lo que podría derivar en riesgos para la estabilidad financiera.



El origen de estos riesgos estaría, tal y como señalan estos dos analistas, en la esencia misma del negocio de estos gigantes bigtech y su estrategia de negocio “de envolvimiento”, probada ya en múltiples sectores.



Así, las grandes tecnológicas como Google o Amazon entran a competir (con éxito casi asegurado por sus precios fuera de mercado) en aquellos segmentos de actividad más rentables, como la originación o la distribución de préstamos. Otras actividades con más costos regulatorios o menos rentables, como la captación de depósitos, en cambio, quedarían al margen de las aspiraciones de estas compañías globales.



Si esta dinámica de entrada en el mercado bancario se acaba reproduciendo (como ya ocurriera en otros sectores), las entidades financieras irán reduciendo progresivamente su peso en la economía, en favor de estos gigantes. Esto podría resultar, según alertan los autores de este estudio, en mercados bancarios todavía más concentrados que en la actualidad, “por lo que nuevos y mayores riesgos morales y problemas de selección adversa podrían amenazar la estabilidad financiera”, advierten.



La solución propuesta por Padilla y De la Mano es limitar la capacidad de estas grandes corporaciones de controlar los datos de millones de usuarios en exclusiva. Así, apuestan porque los reguladores obliguen a compartir estos datos: “Las plataformas a partir de un cierto tamaño tendrán que garantizar el acceso a otros, incluyendo los bancos tradicionales, de los datos transaccionales, incluyendo datos personales, a partir del consentimiento de los clientes”, señalan en las conclusiones del documento presentado.

urn:contentItem:5JM8-XTX1-DYPV-N02S-00000-00Banca Intesa ad Beograd - Daily Report, Apr 25, 20162016-04-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:09ZLexisNexisBanca Intesa ad Beograd - Daily Report, Apr 25, 2016SeeNews

Banka Intesa ad Beograd

DAILY REPORT

MM and fixed income, Equity market

Serbia    

SNS wins most votes in parliamentary, Vojvodina elections - The camp led by outgoing Prime Minister Aleksandar Vucic's Serbian Progressive Party (SNS) won the most votes in

Sunday's parliamentary elections, about 49%, according to estimates by polling agencies and initial results announced by the Election Commission (RIK), local media reported last night. The bloc headed by outgoing First Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Ivica Dacic's Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS) came in second, with about 11%, ahead of ultranationalist Vojislav Seselj's Serbian Radical Party (SRS), with around 8%, and Bojan Pajtic's Democratic Party (DS), with some 6%, according to the estimates. Also expected to enter the parliament, with over 5% of the vote, are former economy minister Sasa Radulovic's Enough is Enough movement and the camp comprising Sanda Raskovic Ivic's Democratic Party of Serbia (DSS) and rightwing movement Dveri, while the bloc comprising former Serbian president Boris Tadic's Social Democratic Party (SDS), Cedomir Jovanovic's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), and Nenad Canak's League of Social Democrats of Vojvodina (LSV) was hovering around the 5% threshold, according to reports. The Alliance of Vojovodina Hungarians (SVM), which has the status of a national minority party, is set to enter the parliament as well, according to local media. Vucic's camp also secured the most votes in the Vojvodina provincial elections, some 45%, according to projections. Following the release of the initial estimates, Vucic addressed reporters, saying that Serbia will press ahead with its EU integration efforts, while maintaining its traditionally friendly relations with Russia, China, and the US.

(Source: Executive newsletter)

(To view the original document, please click on the link below:

http://reports.aiidatapro.com/brokers/BancaIntesa/Daily2016-04-25-Englishversion.pdf) 

Agreement on sale of Smederevo steel maker's assets to China's HBIS posted on Economy Ministry's website - The agreement on the sale of state steel maker Zelezara

Smedrevo's assets to China's steel company HBIS has been posted on the Economy Ministry's website. The agreement was signed on April 18, after HBIS filed a sole, EUR 46 million bid for the assets. The Chinese company plans to complete Zelezara's takeover in late June, HBIS Chairman Yu Yong recalled in an interview with RTS, adding that he hopes the Smederevo steel maker will operate at full capacity by the end of 2017. Zelezara has an annual production capacity of some two million metric tons of steel, he recalled. Outgoing Prime Minister Aleksandar Vucic earlier said that a business plan for the Smederevo steel maker will be signed "around May 20." The business plan will not be unveiled, according to Vucic. (Source: Executive newsletter)

Study on impediments to sale of NPLs in Serbia to help government's working group remove remaining legal, regulatory hurdles before end-2016, finance minister says. A public

presentation of a non-performing loan (NPL) market study, titled Analysis of the Existing Impediments to the Sale of NPLs in Serbia, was held on Friday on the premises on the National Bank of Serbia (NBS), with Finance Minister Dusan Vujovic saying that the study's recommendations will help the government's working group to remove the remaining legal and regulatory obstacles before the end of 2016, Tanjug reported. The study was prepared by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD), in cooperation with KPMG and law firm Schoenherr, according to announcements on the EBRD's and the Finance Ministry's websites. (Source: Executive newsletter)

REGION

Hungary's April Economic Sentiment Index at Lowest Since 2014 - Economic sentiment index drops in April as business outlook deteriorates, GKI research institute says. Economic sentiment index drops to -3.9, lowest since Aug. 2014, from -2.8 in March, while business sentiment index drops to +2.2, lowest since Aug. 2014, from +4.6 in March. Business expectations "noticeably worsened" in all areas except retail, GKI says. Consumer sentiment index improves to -21.1 from -23.8 the previous month. (Source: Bloomberg)

Bulgaria's 2015 public debt-to-GDP ratio narrows to 26.7% - Bulgaria's government debt widened to 23 billion levs ($13.23 billion/11.75 billion euro) at end-2015 from 22.56 billion levs a year earlier, data from Eurostat showed. The debt-to-GDP ratio, however, edged down to 26.7% at the end of last year from 27% at end-2014, ranking the country third in the EU in terms of lowest debt-to-GDP ratio after Estonia (9.7%) and Luxembourg (21.4%), Eurostat said in a statement on Thursday. Bulgaria's general government budget gap narrowed to 1.8 billion levs, or 2.1% of GDP, last year from 4.6 billion levs, or 5.4% in 2014. (Source: Bloomberg)

WORLD

U.S. Stocks Fluctuate Amid Earnings, Crude Rally; Yen Weakens - U.S. stocks fluctuated after erasing declines, with energy and financial shares advancing to offset losses that sent technology gauges tumbling the most in 11 weeks. The yen dropped the most in 17 months. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index erased a 0.5 percent decline as energy producers jumped after crude extended a third weekly gain to $44 a barrel. Alphabet Inc. and Microsoft Corp. tumbled after earnings disappointed, dragging the Nasdaq 100 Index to the biggest drop since Feb. 5. Japan's currency weakened as the Bank of Japan weighed the possibility of offering negative-rate loans to banks. U.S. natural gas futures are having their best week of the year as a supply glut narrows. The nine-week rally that took equities to multimonth highs faltered in the week as investors questioned the efficacy of unprecedented central-bank stimulus even as Europe and Japan signal additional steps are possible. Financial results have so far done little to bolster confidence that economic growth is showing up on corporate balance sheets, with Google parent Alphabet Inc. and Microsoft on Thursday dimming the outlook for earnings. European carmakers are facing renewed scrutiny after Volkswagen cheated on emissions tests. "The news on the economic front has been steady, if not unspectacular, and the earnings picture has been mixed at best," said Mark Luschini, chief investment strategist at Philadelphiabased Janney Montgomery Scott LLC, which manages $54 billion. "The big tech names that have reported in the last day are having a negative influence on major index returns." (Source: Bloomberg)

Europe Stocks Fall for 2nd Day as Daimler Leads Carmakers Lower - European stocks slid further away from a three-month high, trimming a second weekly advance, as carmakers led declines. Daimler AG tumbled 5.1 percent after its quarterly operating profit fell. Volkswagen AG lost 1.3 percent, paring a drop of as much as 6.1 percent, after more than doubling the provisions toward payments in its cheating scandal. PSA Peugeot Citroen fell 1.7 percent after government fraud investigators searched the group's premises in France as part of a probe into vehicle emissions. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index lost 0.3 percent at the close of trading, paring an earlier drop of as much as 0.8 percent. Traders sent the benchmark lower yesterday for the first time in four sessions as they remained unconvinced by the European Central Bank's stimulus program even after President Mario Draghi urged critics to give it time to work. "What we're seeing today is a bit of profit-taking on the gains we've seen in the past couple of weeks," said Michael Hewson, a London-based market analyst at CMC Markets Plc. "I'm not convinced we will see it degenerate into a much deeper selloff in the short to medium term." Advances in commodity and energy producers have led a rally in European equities in the past two months. The Stoxx 600 surged 16 percent from a February low to its highest level since Jan. 6 on Wednesday. It's up 1.7 percent this week. The gains have come even as analysts slashed their profit estimates for the region's companies. They now predict an earnings decline in 2016 for Stoxx 600 firms, reversing calls for growth at the start of the year. Among shares moving on financial results, Kering SA slid 5.4 percent after the Gucci owner reported first-quarter revenue that trailed analysts' estimates. Volvo AB rose 4.9 percent on better-thanestimated earnings. (Source: Bloomberg)

DAILY REPORT

MM and fixed income, Equity market

Serbia    

State power utility EPS GM believes no electricity price hike needed in 2016 - State power utility Elektroprivreda Srbije (EPS) General Manager Aleksandar Obradovic believes that no electricity price hike will be needed in 2016, thanks to a fall in electricity prices in the region and elsewhere in Europe, as well as the fact that EPS has improved its performances thanks to reorganization, in what has included major cost cuts, according to local media. In an interview with TV Pink, Obradovic said that another analysis of trends will be carried out and a conclusion reached in cooperation with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank concerning what should be done with electricity prices, according to reports. (Source: Executive newsletter)

In an interview with TV Pink, Obradovic said that another analysis of trends will be carried out and a conclusion reached in cooperation with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank concerning what should be done with electricity prices, according to reports.September 2015 , up to a maximum of USD 500,000, which will form part of the Stage 1 earn-in expenditure, the news release reads. (Source: Executive newsletter)

Social-economic council settles remaining disputes over draft law on salaries in public sector - The social-economic council settled the remaining disputes over a draft law on

salaries in the public sector at a session attended by Prime Minister Aleksandar Vucic on Saturday, with a bill on salaries in the public sector likely to be sent to the parliament next week for adoption, local media reported. According to reports, the bill's adoption is needed for the World Bank to consider releasing a USD 75 million loan for Serbia. The future law will represent umbrella legislation, with laws regulating specific segments of the public sector to be adopted at a later stage, according to reports. According to Public Administration and Local Government Minister Kori Udovicki, the future law, which will regulate pay for more than 500,000 employees, not including those at public companies, will not hurt any of the workers' rights, while it will give them even more rights in certain segments. She also said that an agreement was reached on how pay grades will be regulated in the coming period, noting that vacation and meal compensation will not be calculated as part of coefficients, but will be in line with the state budget legislation. Local governments will also have to align their base salaries, according to her. Udovicki also said that the planned rightsizing that was supposed to result in 14,000 fewer people working in the public sector by the end of January has been delayed given that the original 60-day deadline for state bodies to submit their reports was short. Of the number, attrition was planned to result in 5,000 fewer jobs, the media recalled. (Source: Executive newsletter)

REGION

Hungary to Raise Public Sector Wages After Headcount Cut - Hungary plans to raise wages in public administration by 50% after lowering sector's headcount, Janos Lazar, minister in charge of prime minister's office says in interview on MR1-Kossuth radio. Government to decide in February on proposal to overhaul/close down 75 public sector institutions. Overhaul of public sector, which accounts for 20% of overall employment vs 10% in Czech Republic or Austria, needed to boost Hungary's competitiveness. (Source: Bloomberg)

Economic growth in Central Europe to slow down to 3.1% - Economic growth in the countries in Central Europe is expected to slow down to a real 3.1% in 2016 from 3.5% forecast for last year, Raiffeisen Research said. The region - comprising Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Croatia, Romania and Serbia - is expected to keep up the steady growth of 3.1% through 2017, Raiffeisen Research said in a report published earlier this week. In 2014 the region's economy expanded by 3%. Bulgaria's gross domestic product (GDP) is seen up by 2.7% in 2015 and by 2.1% in 2016. For 2017, the analysts project 3% growth. Romania will remain the region's top performer with stable growth of 3.7% and 4% expected in 2015 and 2016, respectively, before a slight slow-down to 3.6% in 2017. Serbia, which is expected to have ended 2015 with a growth of 0.5%, is seen posting growth rates of 2.5% and 3% in 2016 and 2017, respectively. Croatia's GDP is seen rising by 1.5% in 2015, by 1.0% in 2016 and then by 1.5% again in 2017. Bosnia and Herzegovina is seen posting an economic growth of 2% in 2015, 3% in 2016 and 3.5% in 2017. For Albania the analysts expect growth of 2.7% in 2015, 3.5% in 2016 and 4% in 2017. (Source: Bloomberg, SeeNews)

WORLD

U.S. Stocks Sink on Tech Rout as Dollar Climbs After Jobs Data - U.S. stocks tumbled, with the Nasdaq 100 Index plunging to its lowest in five months, as disappointing earnings sent consumer and technology shares lower. The dollar advanced after signs of wage growth in America forced investors to reconsider the timing and pace of future interest-rate increases. Losses of more than 6 percent in companies from Netflix Inc. to Amazon.com Inc. sent the Nasdaq gauge lower, as quarterly results in the technology industry fueled selling of some of last year's biggest winners. The Nasdaq Internet Index plunged the most since 2011, while Tableau Software Inc. tumbled almost 50 percent after a miss on licensing revenue, sparking a rout in data-storage firms including Salesforce.com Inc. Yields on 10-year Treasury notes were little changed at 1.84 percent, after falling to 1.79 percent Wednesday. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index rebounded by the most this year, after posting its biggest two-day decline since 2009 earlier this week. Gold climbed and oil closed below $31 a barrel. Concern the U.S. is vulnerable to global headwinds has dominated markets this week, fueling a retreat in the dollar and stocks, and pushing futures traders to price in no Fed rate hikes this year. The Labor Department report unsettled that view, reintroducing the Fed as an element of volatility in markets roiled by China's uncertain growth path and a persistent rout in crude. "Investors are selling the big tech and large-cap names to stem any further losses," said Stephen Carl, principal and head equity trader at Williams Capital Group LP. "Economic numbers were mixed, and the market started off modestly down before starting to make new lows as it went along. You've seen profit-taking going into the weekend as well." (Source: Bloomberg)

European Shares Fall as Oil Drops, U.S. Payrolls Miss Forecasts - European shares declined for a fifth day in volatile trading as investors assessed earnings, oil prices erased gains, and some U.S. payroll data disappointed. ArcelorMittal damped an index of commodity producers, falling 5.5 percent after announcing plans to raise $3 billion from investors and sell a $1 billion stake in Spanish auto-parts maker Gestamp. Total SA and Eni SpA dragged energy stocks lower as oil gave up gains. Automakers posted the best performance on the Stoxx Europe 600 Index, with Nokian Renkaat Oyj contributing the most to progress after reporting better-than-estimated profit. The Stoxx 600 slid 0.9 percent to 325.9 at the close of trading. The measure swung between gains and losses more than 25 times, slipping as much as 1 percent and rising 0.6 percent. It posted a 4.8 percent weekly decline. A gauge tracking equity swings has jumped 36 percent this year as the Stoxx 600 has lost about 11 percent, with concern about bad loans at banks adding to worries about an oil rout and China's economy. "People are seeing the negative effects of the lower prices and still waiting to see the positive," said William Hobbs, head of investment strategy at Barclays Plc's wealth-management unit in London. "Until we see evidence of better consumption it's likely equity markets will be correlated with the oil price and that suggests volatility. Earnings aren't confirming people's worst fears, but they are a bit choppy." (Source: Bloomberg)
